entries.title: Tommy Schaefer arrested for Bali killing of Heather Mack's mother after returning to Chicago
entries.summary: <p>Nearly 12 years after the overseas murder of Oak Park’s Sheila von Wiese-Mack, the FBI on Wednesday arrested<b> </b>the man accused of beating her to death as part of a plot to access the $1.5 million<b> </b>estate that might have been inherited by her then-teenage daughter, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/heather-mack" target="_blank" >Heather Mack</a>.</p><p>Tommy Schaefer’s return to the United States begins what could be the final chapter in a long-running, international legal drama that created tabloid headlines around the globe<b> </b>in 2014 once von Wiese-Mack’s body was found stuffed in a suitcase outside the St. Regis Bali Resort.</p><p>Schaefer is due<b> </b>in a federal courtroom Thursday in Chicago, following his deportation from Indonesia. He was arrested mid-flight on a plane that landed at O'Hare Airport at 8 a.m. according to Joseph Fitzpatrick, a spokesman for U.S. Attorney Andrew Boutros.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2024/1/17/24039349/heather-mack-gets-26-years-in-federal-prison-for-the-murder-of-her-mother-in-bali" >Heather Mack gets 26 years for murder of mom in Bali after stark testimony from family</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Unlike when Mack returned to Chicago in 2021, there is little mystery about what the feds have in store for Schaefer. <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2021/11/3/22761085/heather-mack-returns-chicago-ohare-fbi-charged-conspiracy" target="_blank" >A 2017 indictment</a> charges him with two counts of conspiring to kill von Wiese-Mack and one count of obstruction of justice.<b> </b>It was unsealed in November 2021.</p><p>That means Schaefer has known for at least four years that he’ll face prosecution in Chicago’s federal court. He’s also surely aware that Mack, the mother of his nearly 11-year-old child, is already <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2024/1/17/24039349/heather-mack-gets-26-years-in-federal-prison-for-the-murder-of-her-mother-in-bali" target="_blank" >serving a 26-year sentence</a> in the Federal Bureau of Prisons.</p><p>That’s in addition to seven years Mack spent imprisoned in Indonesia. Schaefer served more than 11 years there before being released and deported from the country<b> </b>this month, according to media reports.</p><p>Mack, now 30, likely has roughly 18 years to serve before she’ll be released in her late 40s. Schaefer’s cousin, Robert Bibbs, also served prison time for his role in the conspiracy. He is now in the custody of a residential re-entry management office in Phoenix, Arizona.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2021/11/3/22761085/heather-mack-returns-chicago-ohare-fbi-charged-conspiracy" >Heather Mack, Tommy Schaefer charged in U.S. indictment with conspiring to kill Mack’s mother</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>U.S. District Judge Matthew Kennelly handed Mack her prison sentence<b> </b>in January 2024. Now Schaefer is expected to face Kennelly Thursday<b> </b>morning.<b> </b>The attorney who once represented Schaefer, Thomas Anthony Durkin, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2025/07/21/thomas-durkin-obituary-chicago-defense-lawyer" target="_blank" >died in 2025</a>, so it’s unclear who will represent him now.</p><p>If Mack’s case is any guide, it could take years to resolve Schaefer’s U.S. prosecution.</p><p>The legal saga that followed von Wiese-Mack’s murder involved an aggressive FBI investigation, civil litigation reaching from the Daley Center to Indonesia, a bizarre YouTube confession, an Indonesian trial interrupted by the birth of Mack’s child, and seven years of questions about whether the couple would ever face consequences in the United States.</p><p>Meanwhile, media outlets have long labeled von Wiese-Mack’s death the “Bali Suitcase Murder.”<b> </b>Mack’s exploits as a young, attractive and notorious killer in an Indonesian jail fueled the coverage further.</p><p>Her return to Chicago also triggered a legal battle over custody of her daughter, Estelle Schaefer. A Cook County judge in 2023 named a maternal cousin of Mack’s as the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2023/2/21/23609430/heather-mack-stella-sheila-von-wiese-mack-dead-murder-bali-suitcase-murder" target="_blank" >guardian of the girl</a>, better known as Stella. The cousin’s mother is von Wiese-Mack’s sister.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-330000" name="image-330000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" </div> </div><p>It wasn’t until June 2023 that <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2023/6/16/23763322/heather-mack-pleads-guilty-murder-mother-bali-2014" target="_blank" >Mack admitted plotting</a> her mother’s murder. In all, it took 26 months for her U.S. prosecution to play out once she landed at O’Hare.</p><p>Mack apologized to her mother’s siblings during her January 2024 sentencing. She also said she loved and missed von Wiese-Mack.</p><p>“There’s not a day that goes by that I don’t think of her,” Mack said. “I miss her smile, her ‘I love yous,’ and mostly her holding me.”</p><p>Authorities <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2024/1/11/24032878/heather-mack-bali-suitcase-murder-feds-prison-sentence-28-years" target="_blank" >documented a long history of violence</a> in the Mack home before the murder — how Mack allegedly bit her mother, shoved her to the ground so hard that von Wiese-Mack broke her arm, and at one point went around their home breaking plates and picture frames during an argument over household chores.</p><p>Mack broached the idea of killing her mother with Schaefer as early as February 2014, the feds say. Schaefer wrote in a Facebook chat that month, “that b---- heather is crazy” and added “she asked me to find someone to kill her mom for 50k.”</p><p>The feds say Mack ultimately enlisted Schaefer, secretly booking a $12,000 plane ticket for him so he could rendezvous with her while she vacationed with her mother in Bali in August 2014.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2015/9/24/18424089/heather-mack-traded-giddy-tense-texts-with-boyfriend-before-mom-s-murder" >Heather Mack traded giddy, tense texts with boyfriend before mom’s murder</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Then, over the course of nearly 40 minutes on the morning of Aug. 12, 2014, prosecutors say Mack and Schaefer exchanged tense, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2015/9/24/18424089/heather-mack-traded-giddy-tense-texts-with-boyfriend-before-mom-s-murder" target="_blank" >excited text messages</a> as they prepared to murder von Wiese-Mack. They allegedly used the phrase “saying hi” as code for the killing, and they referred to each other as Bonnie and Clyde.</p><p>Soon after, prosecutors say, von Wiese-Mack “was brutally beaten after being taken by surprise as she lay in her hotel bed.” Mack’s plea agreement alleged that Schaefer “repeatedly beat Von Wiese in the head and face,” ending her life.</p><p>Prosecutors once alleged that Mack <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2022/12/5/23495745/heather-mack-was-directly-involved-in-mothers-murder-should-stay-in-jail-feds" target="_blank" >covered her mother’s mouth</a> with her hand during the killing, but Mack did not admit to it in court.</p>

entries.title: What we know about Rev. Jesse Jackson's death and plans to honor his life
entries.summary: <p>The Rev. Jesse Jackson <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-rainbow-push-obituary" target="_blank" >“died peacefully”</a> Feb. 17, his family said during a news conference last week. He was 84. </p><p>Jackson is a Chicago icon known for his work as a civil rights leader. "All are welcome" for services scheduled this week, according to his family.</p><h3>When are services?</h3><p>Jackson will lie in repose <b>Thursday </b>and <b>Friday</b>, at Rainbow PUSH's Kenwood headquarters at 930 E. 50th St. The services both days will start at 10 a.m. Doors will close to the public and media at 9 p.m. </p><p>The service dates were adjusted after officials in South Carolina and Washington, D.C., offered to memorialize him there as well, so his remains will be traveling between Sunday and March 5.</p><p>On <b>March 2</b>, a full day of recognition will take place at and near the South Carolina state capitol, according to communications from Rainbow PUSH. </p><p>Jackson will lie in repose at the Statehouse in Columbia before private, public and church services take place throughout the day. The services will be held from 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. at 1100 Gervais St., Columbia, S.C., 29208. </p><p>On <b>March 4</b>, a formal service will take place in Washington, D.C. Details are forthcoming. </p><p>A "People's Celebration" in Chicago will be held at 10 a.m. <b>March 6</b>, at House of Hope, 752 E. 114th St. Doors open at 9 a.m.</p><p>Private homegoing services are scheduled for 10 a.m. <b>March 7</b>, at Rainbow PUSH. Doors open at 8 a.m., with limited capacity. </p><p>Relatives of Jackson said that "all are welcome," regardless of political party.</p><p>"Do not bring your politics, out of respect to Rev. Jesse Jackson and the life that he lived, to these homegoing services. They come respectful and come to say thank you," Jesse Jackson Jr. said during a media event in front of the Jackson family home. "But these homegoing services are welcome to all — Democrat, Republican, liberal and conservative, right wing, left wing, because his life is broad enough to cover the full spectrum of what it means to be an American."</p><p>The family will livestream all services at JesseJacksonLegacy.com. </p><h3>What hotels are recommended for those traveling to Chicago for the events?</h3><p>Those traveling to Chicago to attend services are encouraged to stay at the Hyatt Regency McCormick Place Chicago at 2233 S. Martin Luther King Drive, according to the family's website. Rooms at the hotel have been reserved within a hotel block, with limited availability. </p><h3>Where can people park?</h3><p>For those hoping to attend the Jackson lying in state events, street parking is available at Rainbow PUSH on South Drexel Boulevard, East 49th Street, East Hyde Park Boulevard and East 49th Street. </p><p>For the People's Celebration, parking will be available at House of Hope's parking lot on 113th Street. </p><h3>What security measures will be in place?</h3><p>At each event, security checks and magnetometers will be in place. The family's website asks that individuals limit items brought to smooth the process. Weapons, signs and any items that could disrupt services are prohibited</p><p>For more information on the scheduled services visit <a class="Link" href="https://www.jessejacksonlegacy.com/" target="_blank" >jessejacksonlegacy.com</a>. </p><h3>Where will the Rev. Jesse Jackson be buried?</h3><p>Jackson will be buried at <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/curious-city/2025/06/04/prejudice-follows-us-to-the-grave-the-segregated-past-of-chicago-cemeteries#:~:text=Mayor%20Harold%20Washington%20is%20buried,bring%20it%20to%20an%20end." target="_blank" >Oak Woods Cemetery</a>, the largest cemetery on the South Side, in Greater Grand Crossing. Former Chicago Mayor Harold Washington, journalist and civil rights activist Ida B. Wells and Olympic athlete Jesse Owens are among those buried there.</p><p></p><p></p><p></p><h3>How did he die?</h3><p>While his family has not given an official cause of death nor said where he died, Jackson had been declining in health for a decade before his death. In 2015,<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2017/11/17/18375473/rev-jesse-jackson-announces-parkinson-s-diagnosis" > Jackson was initially diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease</a>, but he revealed last April that he actually had progressive supranuclear palsy.</p><h3>How is the political world reacting to his death?</h3><p>Political figures from across the country have weighed in to pay their respects and honor his legacy. </p><p>In a joint statement, former President Barack Obama and former first lady Michelle Obama wrote: "Michelle and I will always be grateful for Jesse's lifetime of service, and the friendship our families share. We stood on his shoulders. We send our deepest condolences to the Jackson family and everyone in Chicago and beyond who knew and loved him." </p><p>President Donald Trump also extended his sympathies to Jackson's family in a statement posted to Truth Social last week. </p><p>"I knew him well, long before becoming President," he said. "He was very gregarious — Someone who truly loved people! Despite the fact that I am falsely and consistently called a Racist by the Scoundrels and Lunatics on the Radical Left, Democrats ALL, it was always my pleasure to help Jesse along the way."</p><p>Chicago leaders, including Mayor Brandon Johnson and Gov. JB Pritzker, also shared their condolences. </p><p>"In honor of Rev. Jackson's service, and as our city mourns, the Chicago flag will lower to half-staff," Mayor Johnson wrote in a statement. </p><p>Pritzker also ordered all flags across the state to fly at half-mast to honor him in a statement posted on social media.</p><p>"He broke down barriers, inspired generations, and kept hope alive. Our state, nation, and world are better due to his years of service," Pritzker said.</p><h3>How are Chicagoans reacting to his death?</h3><p>Across the city, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/02/17/jesse-jackson-chicago-remembers" >Chicago residents mourned Jackson’s death</a> and urged that his legacy continue. </p><p>Martin Travis, a congregant of Apostolic Church of God in Woodlawn, said in his youth, his parents brought him to demonstrations organized by Operation Breadbasket, a movement Jackson led. </p><p>Now, 64, Travis remembers Jackson as "instrumental in fighting for justice and freedom for all people."</p><p>Chloe Gould, 41, a Bronzeville resident, said that his death hit "like you lost a family member." </p><p>In the wake of his death, she said she worries about the future of civil rights activism, as other activists and leaders have not stepped in to fill his shoes. </p><p>"Who is gonna be the civil rights activist now?" she asked. </p>

entries.title: Man and his dog shot after telling speeding driver to 'slow down' in West Pullman
entries.summary: <p>A man and his dog were shot and wounded after he told a speeding driver to "slow down" Tuesday morning in West Pullman on the Far South Side. </p><p>The 50-year-old man was on his porch as he was warming up his car around 7:25 a.m. Tuesday in the 300 block of East 117th Street when he yelled at a speeding red vehicle to "slow down," according to Chicago police reports obtained by the Sun-Times.</p><p>The red vehicle then circled back around and an armed individual opened fire, striking the man and his dog, police said. Eight spent shell casings were recovered from the scene, police said. </p><p>The man was taken to the Advocate Christ Medical Center in Oak Lawn with gunshot wounds to his abdomen and buttocks and was reported in good condition, officials said. </p><p>The man's dog was shot in the shoulder and was also in good condition, police said. </p><p>No one was in custody. </p>

entries.title: Chicago foundation awards $15 million for construction of two West Side community centers
entries.summary: <p>Richard Townsell’s two children grew up playing sports, which often meant driving 45 minutes to an hour to practices held outside of city limits.</p><p>And if practice didn't involve travel, it required a bit of extra work.</p><p>“I coach [wrestling] at Chicago Hope Academy. We practice on the basketball court, and we have to roll up the mats at the end of every single practice,” Townsell, executive director of Lawndale Christian Development Corp., said. “We have an old facility, and that’s the case for many Chicago Public School athletes. They don’t have a permanent facility.”</p><p>But that will soon change for many students and youth on the West Side.</p><p>The Chicago-based Lohengrin Foundation announced Wednesday that Lawndale Christian Development and Erie Neighborhood House will receive $10 million and $5 million, respectively, for the construction of two new West Side youth and community centers. </p><p>The award stems from the foundation's Thriving Youth, Stronger Communities initiative, which launched in 2024 to help create environments where Chicago youth can grow and thrive.</p><p>Lawndale Christian Development and Erie Neighborhood House are the first to receive the award, Lohengrin Foundation CEO Mark Rodriguez said. </p><p>The $10 million will support Lawndale Christian Development's project, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2025/11/20/plan-commission-approves-depaul-practice-facility-morgan-park-commons" >One Lawndale</a>, that was approved by the City Council in late 2025. </p><p>The prize “makes [One Lawndale] possible,” Richard Townsell, Lawndale Christian Development's executive director, said.</p><p>“With Lohengrin being first in, it helps to secure everybody else,” Townsell said. He said an award of this size can help attract additional investors and funding.</p><p>One Lawndale, at the corner of South Springfield Avenue and West Cermak Road, will be a first-of-its-kind sports complex for the West Side. The $38 million indoor sports and recreation center will allow for year-round sports, with two indoor turf fields, six full-size basketball courts, a boxing and fitness room, wrestling studio, multipurpose room, concessions and bar area and a pro shop.</p><p>Sports leagues, mentoring programs and other initiatives will be helmed by Black- and Latino-led partners from both North Lawndale and Little Village.</p><p>One goal of the Thriving Youth, Stronger Communities initiative is to create safe spaces for youth to aid in violence prevention.</p><p>Townsell believes One Lawndale will achieve that as it will also offer nutrition, mental health and mentoring programs.</p><p>“We think that some of the best violence prevention work that you can do is work with young people before they get engaged in behavior out of boredom or having nothing else really to do,” Townsell said. “For us to be able to have something like this in the neighborhood that is high quality and that has all of the other supports necessary, we think it's going to be the best violence prevention and community building effort.”</p><p>The Lohengrin Foundation is helping the developer find other foundation partners to close its funding gap, Townsell said. It hopes to start construction in late summer or early fall. Completion is slated for fall or winter of 2027.</p><p>Erie Neighborhood House will use its $5 million award toward the La Villita Erie House Center.</p><p>The social services nonprofit has been in Little Village for about 20 years. It currently rents a building in the neighborhood.</p><p>La Villita Erie House, 2653-59 S. Kildare Ave., will allow the nonprofit to grow its footprint in the neighborhood — both in the number of people it serves and into a larger, permanent space. The five-story building will have spaces for children, teens and other community members, with the final concept shaped by community input.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div Foundation</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Cristina De La Rosa, executive director of Erie Neighborhood House, said community members have continuously expressed a need for safety. The nonprofit hosted focus groups and distributed surveys to hear more from community members about what a safe space for residents would look like and what sort of programming they’d like to see at the new center.</p><p>“We wanted to be really intentional,” De La Rosa said. “We really wanted to make sure that when people walk into the building, they felt like they could see themselves there — that it was designed for them.”</p><p>The result is a center with a full-size gymnasium, flexible classrooms, an arts studio, private counseling and therapy offices, teen and tech lounges, community kitchen, outdoor green spaces, rooftop playground and children’s garden.</p><p>Erie Neighborhood House already offers a suite of youth programming, but the new center will allow the organization to offer full-day after school programming, De La Rosa said. And in the summer, school-aged children can stay during the week and receive breakfast, lunch and a snack.</p><p>Erie Neighborhood House hopes to break ground this fall and open within a year of its groundbreaking. The $22 million project will expand opportunities for the nonprofit to partner with other organizations in the area — like One Lawndale.</p><p>“We don't see this as two separate neighborhoods,” Townsell said of North Lawndale and Little Village. “We see this as one Lawndale and folks coming together around supporting young people.”</p><p>Rodriguez said the foundation didn’t intend to choose two winners, let alone two from adjacent neighborhoods. But the award is helping to connect both projects with possible capital partners, doubling its intended impact.</p><p>North Lawndale and Little Village have higher numbers of youth and youth violence, according to the foundation. The number of youth the projects would serve, along with each project's feasibility, helped elevate the two proposals.</p><p>There were more than 70 submissions for Thriving Youth, Stronger Communities, which showcases the excitement in supporting youth communities, Rodriguez said.</p><p>“There's no limit on the ideas or the need. It's only a limit on the resources that are available,” he said.</p>

entries.title: Ald. Shirley Drewenski elected acting Harvey mayor
entries.summary: <p>The Harvey City Council elected an acting mayor one month after the death of <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/01/30/harvey-mayor-christopher-j-clark-dead" target="_blank" >Mayor Christopher Clark</a>.</p><p>Ald. Shirley Drewenski (1st) was unanimously selected during Monday’s city council meeting and was sworn in to serve the remainder of Clark’s term through next year.</p><p>Drewenski had previously been sworn in as mayor pro tempore after Clark’s death. Her appointment comes after two prior council votes ended in ties. A majority vote is required for the appointment.</p><p>"I accept this responsibility with humility and a deep sense of duty to the residents of Harvey. Our focus remains on stability, transparency, and continuing the work of city government while honoring the legacy of Mayor Christopher Clark," Drewenski said in a statement. </p><p>"This is a time for unity and respect. I am committed to working collaboratively with the City Council, city staff, and our community to ensure continuity in leadership and service. Above all, we will continue to keep Mayor Clark’s family in our thoughts as we move forward together."</p><p>Clark died Jan. 30 and had served as mayor for six years. The cause of his death has not been revealed.</p><p>A memorial service will be held for Clark on March 28, according to the city.<br></p>
entries.author: Cindy Hernandez

entries.title: Man gunned down in Washington Heights
entries.summary: <p>Police are looking for a gunman who opened fire at a parking lot in the Washington Heights neighborhood, killing a 32-year-old acquaintance on Tuesday afternoon. </p><p>Antoine Alexander, 32, was at a parking lot at 9411 S. Ashland Ave. about 3:30 p.m. when someone he knows walked up to him and shot him in the abdomen, police and the Cook County medical examiner's office said. </p><p>Alexander, of the Auburn Gresham neighborhood, was taken to Advocate Christ Medical Center in Oak Lawn, where he was pronounced dead at 9:27 p.m., according to the medical examiner's office. </p><p>A gun was recovered from the scene, according to police. </p><p>Detectives are investigating. <br></p>

entries.title: Acusan a mujer por el asesinato de un repartidor de Uber Eats en el lado oeste
entries.summary: <p>Una mujer de Maywood fue acusada el martes tras el asesinato de Daniel L. Figueroa, de 28 años, quien estaba entregando comida cuando ocurrió el ataque en el lado oeste de la ciudad.</p><p>Montoya Perry, de 33 años, enfrenta cargos por asesinato y robo de vehículo, indicaron las autoridades.</p><p>Figueroa, de 28 años, se encontraba en la cuadra 5500 al oeste de Flournoy Street cuando <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2026/02/23/death-of-downers-grove-man-found-on-austin-street-probed-as-homicide-police-say" target="_blank" >fue atacado a eso de las 2:10 a.m. del lunes, según la policía.</a></p><p>Figueroa, de Westmont, un suburbio al oeste, fue llevado al Hospital Mount Sinai, donde fue declarado muerto a las 2:46 a.m., según la Oficina del Médico Forense del Condado de Cook. La causa y el modo de su muerte no se conocieron de inmediato. Una autopsia realizada el martes fue inconclusa y está pendiente de más estudios, según indicó la oficina.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-060000" name="module-060000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>“Estamos increíblemente tristes por esta trágica pérdida, y nuestros pensamientos están con su familia y seres queridos mientras navegan por este momento inimaginablemente difícil”, dijo un comunicado enviado por correo electrónico de Uber. “Nos hemos comunicado con la policía y los asistiremos en lo que podamos”.</p><p>El tiroteo ocurrió frente al Hospital Loretto. WGN TV reportó que Figueroa estaba entregando comida a un médico en el hospital.</p><p>En un comunicado, un portavoz del Hospital Loretto expresó que estaban al tanto del “trágico incidente” y que los funcionarios del hospital están cooperando plenamente con las autoridades locales.</p><p>“En nombre del Hospital Loretto, nuestras oraciones y condolencias van para la familia y seres queridos del individuo”, dijo el portavoz. “Nuestro enfoque sigue siendo apoyar la seguridad, salud y bienestar de la comunidad que servimos durante este difícil momento”.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>

entries.title: Bulls' Matas Buzelis can't stop the losing but can learn from a 'talk'
entries.summary: <p>Billy Donovan talks with his players daily.</p><p>Monday, however, was different for the Bulls coach and second-year forward Matas Buzelis.</p><p>It wasn’t just talk, it was “the talk.”</p><p>Buzelis strolled into the Advocate Center around 8 p.m. looking to get some extra work in, and of course Donovan was in his foxhole trying to figure out a way to stop the losing.</p><p>The heart-to-heart was inevitable.</p><p>Donovan’s basic message to Buzelis was to reiterate staying aggressive with his shot, especially from beyond three-point range, but also reaffirming that the mid-range is not off limits for Buzelis like many believe, it’s the bad mid-range that Donovan wants out of Buzelis’ game.</p><p>Somewhere between high school and playing for G League Ignite, Buzelis developed a bad habit of getting to his mid-range and then fading back off one leg on his shot. One guy in the history of the league was lethal at that and his first was Dirk.</p><p>Matas Buzelis is no Dirk Nowitzki. Maybe someday, but nowhere near that yet.</p><p>Instead, Donovan wants Buzelis using his ball-handling to either attack the rim or thrust an opposing defender back, going to the mid-range if he can create that space.</p><p>The sample size was just one game – a blowout loss to Charlotte on Wednesday – but Buzelis finished with a career-high 32 points on 13-of-19 shooting. He was 6-of-11 from three, but also took two mid-range shots, going 1-for-2.</p><p>Both were Donovan approved.</p><p>“He got into the paint area and made some shots, got to the basket and made some drives,” Donovan said of Buzelis’ night. “That’s what he’s got to do, play more off the dribble to score. I thought he was very efficient and decisive.</p><p>“If you look at the really good offensive players and scorers in this league, they are hard to guard because you really are not sure what they are going to do. Go by you, step back, shoot a three, shot fake. It’s hard to handle those high-level offensive players. I’ve talked to Matas. He has to be shiftier and craftier with the basketball.”</p><p>Baby steps.</p><p>Buzelis acknowledged the talk with Donovan but didn’t feel the need to detail it. His game against the Hornets was his statement.</p><p>What was also nice was the seven rebounds and even two assists from Buzelis. On a sinking ship that is the 2025-26 season, Buzelis can still be that defiant waving flag in all its glory hanging off the stern.</p><p>He’s just not in the mindset to focus on that. A 10-game losing streak will do that to a man.</p><p>“I’m going to be what the team needs me to be,” Buzelis said. “If that’s scoring, that’s what it’s going to be. I try to figure out during the game what the team needs and (Tuesday) it was scoring. But look at (Detroit point guard) Cade Cunningham the other day (in a blowout win over the Bulls). He was dimeing (making pinpoint passes). That’s what winners do.”</p><p>That, however, is not where the Bulls currently reside. With 23 games left, Buzelis should be focused on continuing his development, shot profile, and making winning plays, but for a losing product. Not an easy sell.</p><p>“The trades happened,” Buzelis said of the roster turnover at the trade deadline. “When you trade half the team and bring in new guys, it’s tough. But it’s no excuse. When we control the things we can control, we are going to be a great team. Billy always says you get 10 guys who are on the same page and ready to fight and you can win anything.”</p><p>A nice thought but just not reality. That might be a heart-to-heart for another day.</p>

entries.title: Trump declara supuesta ‘edad de oro’ de Estados Unidos mientras seis demócratas de Illinois boicotean su discurso
entries.summary: <p>Mientras los habitantes de Chicago afectados por el “Operativo Midway Blitz” del presidente Donald Trump se sentaban como invitados en la Cámara de Representantes, el presidente declaró que el país estaba en una “edad de oro” y se jactó de la seguridad fronteriza, los recortes de impuestos y su aplicación selectiva de la ley contra quienes carecen de estatus legal.</p><p>Casi una hora después del discurso del Estado de la Unión, el más largo en la historia, el presidente pidió a los miembros que se pusieran de pie si creían que “el primer deber del gobierno estadounidense es proteger a los ciudadanos estadounidenses, no a los inmigrantes ilegales”. Los demócratas permanecieron sentados, algunos moviendo la cabeza, mientras que los republicanos se levantaron.</p><p>Los representantes Ilan Omar, demócrata por Minnesota, y Rashida Tlaib, demócrata por Michigan, gritaron a Trump desde sus asientos, mientras él hablaba sobre la inmigración ilegal y se reafirmaba en su ataque contra las denominadas ciudades santuario del Partido Demócrata, incluyendo Chicago.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-d50000" name="module-d50000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>“También les pido que terminen con las mortales ciudades santuario que protegen a los criminales y que impongan serias sanciones a los funcionarios públicos que bloqueen la deportación de inmigrantes criminales, en muchos casos, capos de drogas, asesinos en todo nuestro país”, dijo Trump. “Están bloqueando la deportación de estas personas de nuestro país, y deberían sentirse avergonzados”.</p><p>Y a pesar de haber tomado medidas para restringir la entrada de personas al país, a menudo en nombre de proteger la seguridad nacional, Trump habló sobre dejar entrar a las personas en el país “legalmente”.</p><p>“Siempre permitiremos que las personas entren legalmente”, agregó Trump. “Personas que amarán a nuestro país y trabajarán arduamente para mantenerlo”.</p><p>Los comentarios de Trump sobre sus medidas de inmigración se dieron cuando el representante Jesús “Chuy” García llevó a Marimar Martínez, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/04/marimar-martinez-baleada-por-agentes-de-migracion-se-pronuncia-contra-asesinatos" target="_blank" >una mujer a la que agentes de la Patrulla Fronteriza le dispararon cinco veces</a>, como su invitada.</p><p>El representante Raja Krishnamoorthi llevó como invitado al <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/25/estudiante-de-uic-asiste-al-estado-de-la-union-tras-la-deportacion-de-su-padre" target="_blank" >estudiante de la Universidad de Illinois en Chicago, Jaime Coria Jr, cuyo padre fue detenido</a> por agentes federales durante el clímax del Operativo Midway Blitz y enviado a más de 2,000 millas de distancia a la Ciudad de México.</p><p>García publicó una foto de Martínez en su cuenta de X.</p><p>“Mientras su propio gobierno sigue desacreditando su nombre, estoy orgulloso de su valentía al compartir su historia —y orgulloso de tenerla como mi invitada en el SOTU (Discurso sobre el Estado de la Unión)”, <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/RepChuyGarcia/status/2026485393734951227?s=20" target="_blank" >escribió García</a>.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Marimar Martinez—shot five times by a CBP agent, who later bragged about it—is in the House chambers for the State of the Union.<br>As her own government continues to smear her name, I’m proud of her courage in sharing her story—and proud to have her as my guest at the SOTU. <a href="https://t.co/UM163kS9DW">pic.twitter.com/UM163kS9DW</a></p>— Congressman Chuy García (@RepChuyGarcia) <a href="https://twitter.com/RepChuyGarcia/status/2026485393734951227?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 25, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>La representante Lauren Underwood, demócrata por Naperville, la jefa de la campaña de reclutamiento de candidatos de los demócratas de la Cámara, abandonó la cámara durante el discurso de Trump. Underwood sacudió la cabeza mientras se levantaba para irse.</p><p>La demócrata de Illinois se despidió de algunas de sus colegas mujeres demócratas. Las mujeres, que llevaban vestimenta blanca en homenaje al movimiento sufragista, intercambiaron risas antes de que Underwood saliera rápidamente por la parte trasera.</p><p>También lo hizo el representante Al Green, demócrata por Texas, quien fue escoltado por seguridad tras sostener un letrero que decía “Las personas negras no son simios”, que le fue quitado por el líder de la mayoría en la Cámara, Steve Scalise. Esto se refirió a un video <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/donald-trump/2026/02/06/donald-trump-racist-video-barack-michelle-obama-depiction-primates" target="_blank" >racista</a> que Trump compartió a principios de mes que incluía una representación del expresidente Barack Obama y Michelle Obama como simios en una jungla.</p><p>La senadora Tammy Duckworth, junto con los representantes Mike Quigley, Sean Casten, Delia Ramírez, Jan Schakowsky y Eric Sorensen, boicotearon el discurso anual, con Duckworth calificándolo el lunes como “otro mitin de campaña lleno de mentiras”.</p><p>"La madre de un ángel", Jacqueline Medina, fue una de las muchas invitadas que Trump trajo al discurso. La hija de Medina, Lizbeth, fue supuestamente asesinada por un hombre mexicano que carecía de estatus legal en diciembre de 2023.</p><p>“Su madre destrozada está en la galería para recordarle a todos en esta cámara exactamente por qué estamos deportando a los criminales inmigrantes ilegales en números récord,” dijo Trump entre aplausos de los republicanos. “Y los estamos sacando de aquí rápido”.</p><p>Antes de la retórica política, Trump trató de pintar un panorama optimista sobre sus logros del primer año —y las bajas calificaciones de aprobación— antes de las elecciones de medio término de noviembre. El presidente alabó los aranceles generalizados y lamentó la decisión de la Corte Suprema que los anuló, calificándola de “desafortunada”, mientras la cámara mostraba a los jueces de la Corte Suprema en el recinto.</p><p>“Está salvando a nuestro país”, dijo Trump sobre los aranceles, mientras también los calificaba de “protectores de la paz”.</p><p>El presidente presentó al equipo olímpico ganador de la medalla de oro del hockey sobre hielo masculino en la Cámara, recibiendo aplausos, y anunció que otorgará la Medalla Presidencial de la Libertad al portero del equipo, Connor Hellebuyck.</p><p>Trump recibió una ovación poco común de algunos demócratas, incluyendo la senadora Elizabeth Warren, demócrata por Massachusetts, cuando dijo que deseaba que el Congreso aprobara una medida para detener el comercio de acciones con información privilegiada.</p><p><i>Con información de AP </i></p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>

entries.title: Review: Gogol Bordello’s message of why immigrants matter has never been stronger
entries.summary: <p>Gogol Bordello has always been a band without borders. For more than 25 years, the group’s high-spirited gypsy-punk rock has been a cultural bridge, built from the musical touchstones of Eastern Europe, Russia, Latin and South America and the Lower East Side of New York where the band first sprouted in 1999. But that message has never been stronger than right now.</p><p>“This song is about the journey of where I’m from to where she’s from,” front man Eugene Hütz said Tuesday at Concord Music Hall, introducing the new track, “From Boyarka To Boyaca.” It was co-written and performed with tour opener Puzzled Panther, the title referencing the nearly identical names of Hütz’s hometown of Boyarka, Ukraine, as well as Boyaca, Colombia, where Puzzled Panther’s Victoria Espinoza hails from, illuminating how similar we all are — even worlds away.</p><p>As the two bands crowded the stage, nearly tripping over each other as they pogoed along to the rhythm, a few fans in the crowd held up a large blue-and-yellow Ukrainian flag that came in the eyesight of Hütz who nodded at the sentiment.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-f30000" name="image-f30000"></a> <picture For years, he has stood up for his people and raised money for victims and soldiers of the war via benefit concerts and secret shows, including a performance at the World Forum for Democracy in Strasbourg in November. Gogol Bordello also recorded a cover of Angelic Upstarts’ “Solidarity” with Joy Division/New Order’s Bernard Sumner with lyrics reframed as a tribute to the people of Ukraine. It’s included on Gogol Bordello’s latest album, “We Mean It, Man!” released Feb. 13.</p><p>Perhaps in honor of the anniversary, the band diverted from its standard tour track list on Tuesday to include “Solidarity” as the final song in the encore, with Hütz dedicating it to “our brothers and sisters of Ukraine” before unfurling powerful lyrics like, “In unity there is each other and your friend becomes your brother, and the tyrant will never have its way.”</p><p> Political messages continued throughout the night — before a defiant performance of “Immigraniada (We Comin' Rougher),” percussionist and MC Pedro Erazo had some words to share. “Every day we see police brutality and the destruction of humanity when what we need is peace, love and unity,” he said, adding, “f--- ICE and f--- Trump.” Hütz also took a moment to explain the meaning of the new song, “No Time For Idiots” in the “academic part of the night.” As he noted, the English word idiot comes from ancient Greece and was simply a name for a layperson who is not involved in any politics or public affairs. “I got no f---ing time for that!” he declared. <b></b></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6de953c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6776x3803+0+359/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F7b%2F2c%2F6dae2d964cf4ab342179c24755bf%2Fgogol-2602260919.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b2b70bd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6776x3803+0+359/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F7b%2F2c%2F6dae2d964cf4ab342179c24755bf%2Fgogol-2602260919.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6de953c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6776x3803+0+359/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F7b%2F2c%2F6dae2d964cf4ab342179c24755bf%2Fgogol-2602260919.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Erica Mancini and Gil Alexandre of Gogol Bordello perform Tuesday at Concord Music Hall.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Hütz had also brandished his own blue-and-yellow Ukrainian flag during the night during the optimist chant of “Life Is Possible Again.” The song is one of the most uplifting numbers on “We Mean It, Man!” and is polished with electronic synths and a futuristic vibe that is carried throughout the new album.</p><p>Like the centuries-old music traditions it borrows from, Gogol Bordello uses music as a coping mechanism in times of strife, and the band still wants you to dance and have fun. It’s an easy ask. Decked out in sequins and leopard prints, the lively-as-ever seven-piece ensemble was ready to party and invited the sold-out room to join them for two hours as they sloshed beer cans, galloped around the stage and coaxed the “choir” on the floor to add to the vocal hooting and hollering.</p><p>Anyone who had no idea who Gogol Bordello was and happened to walk into Concord Music Hall might’ve mistaken it for a raucous wedding party with violins and accordions flailing and varied percussion creating a beat that the onlookers in the crowd took to. On fan favorites like bar song “Alcohol” and the feisty “Fire On Ice Floe,” many broke out in jigs and healthy circle pits, swaying arms and stomping their feet on the floor so forcefully that it felt like it could give way at any moment.</p><p><b></b> There’s a reason this band often plays Riot Fest — you almost need the wide outdoor space at Douglass Park to provide ample room for people to fully feel the music. In fact, the band’s “very good friend” Riot Mike (aka fest founder Mike Petryshyn) was in the crowd Tuesday. <b></b></p><p>Gogol Bordello may hail from New York (and its members from all over the world), but its heart has long been in Chicago, and the band made sure to make that fully known on this local tour stop.</p><p>“We have a great history with this city,” Hütz shared, noting that accordionist Erica Mancini is a Chicago native before shouting out Steve Albini with whom the band made the landmark album, “Gypsy Punks: Underdog World Strike” in 2005. That record dominated much of the set list, from the traditional gypsy style of “Mishto!” to the band’s breakaway hit “Start Wearing Purple” that riled everyone up before the encore.</p><p>As Hütz ended the show by inviting all bands out on stage and introducing the nations where each hailed from, it was a powerful message of why immigrants matter and what harmony can be made when we all come together.</p><p><b></b></p><h3>Gogol Bordello set list Feb. 24 at Concord Music Hall</h3><p>Ignition<br>I Would Never Wanna Be Young Again<br>Not A Crime<br>Immigrant Punk<br>Wonderlust King<br>My Companjera<br>Fire On Ice Floe (with Puzzled Panther)<br>From Boyarka To Boyaca (with Puzzled Panther)<br>Mystics<br>No Time For Idiots<br>Immigraniada (We Comin' Rougher)<br>We Mean It, Man!<br>Life Is Possible Again<br>Mishto!<br>Start Wearing Purple<br>Pala Tute</p><p><b>Encore</b><br>Alcohol<br>Boiling Point<br>Solidarity</p>

entries.title: Cubs' Tyler Austin undergoes knee surgery, expected to be out for months
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. — <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a> first baseman <b>Tyler Austin</b> underwent a surgical cleanup on his right knee Tuesday and is expected to be out for months, manager Craig Counsell announced.</p><p>“He’d come into camp, and there is some history of knee issues, and it just didn't respond well early,” Counsell said Wednesday morning.</p><p>It became clear that a patellar tendon debridement would be necessary. Austin’s surgery was one of three injury updates Counsell provided Wednesday. In addition, left-hander <b>Jordan Wicks</b> has been dealing with inflammation in his left forearm, and first baseman <b>Jonathon Long</b>’s recovery from a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/21/how-tokyo-series-prepared-cubs-matthew-boyd-for-wbc-ramp-up" >sprained left elbow</a> has slowed.</p><p>Austin,<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/01/08/how-cubs-tyler-austin-made-his-mlb-comeback-after-six-seasons-in-japan" > after landing a split contract and 40-man roster spot with the Cubs this offseason</a>, entered camp with an “inside track,” as Counsell put it, to breaking camp with the team.</p><p>A former top Yankees prospect, Austin is aiming to return to MLB this season after six seasons in Japan’s Nippon Professional Baseball. His signing provided a right-handed bat off the Cubs bench to pair with left-handed-hitting Michael Busch. </p><p>Already, Busch was expected to get more at-bats against left-handed pitchers this season than in years past. Now, the Cubs’ depth behind him is thin.</p><p>Could they pursue an outside addition to address the loss?</p><p>“You go through this exercise in spring training of backup plans on top of backup plans,” Counsell said. “And you just can't be covered ideally in every single situation.”</p><p>Long, who hit .305 in Triple-A last year, is a backup option.</p><p>“Whether he's with the big-league team or whether he's in Triple-A, he's a day away,” Counsell said.</p><p>Designated hitter and catcher Moisés Ballesteros is also expected to take reps at first base this spring. And the Cubs have a number of options in emergency situations.</p><h3>Long’s decision</h3><p>Long was originally scheduled to leave Tuesday to join Team Chinese Taipei for the World Baseball Classic, but he pushed back his travel date after spraining his left elbow in an in-game collision Saturday.</p><p>Long’s latest injury update throws his availability for the tournament into question.</p><p>“Things are going a little more slowly, probably, on the recovery, than we'd all like,” Counsell said Wednesday. “So he has a WBC decision to make.”</p><h3>Wicks avoids worst case</h3><p>A recent MRI of Wicks’ throwing arm didn’t raise any concerns about the stability of his ulnar collateral ligament, Counsell said. The Cubs are still trying to find the exact source of Wicks’ discomfort, but the imaging results suggest he won’t need Tommy John surgery.</p><p>Wicks has taken the last five days off of throwing, Counsell said, and responded well.</p><p>“In terms of length of time down, we're probably still looking just at days down, not weeks,” Counsell said.</p><p></p><bsp-listcarousel class="PageListE" entries.title: Estudiante de UIC asiste al Estado de la Unión tras la deportación de su padre; ahora él cuida a sus hermanas
entries.summary: <p>Menos de un año después de que el estudiante universitario Jaime Coria Jr. perdiera a su madre a causa de un tipo raro de cáncer, su padre fue detenido por agentes federales durante el apogeo del Operativo Midway Blitz y enviado a más de 2,000 millas de distancia a la Ciudad de México.</p><p>En los meses transcurridos desde entonces, Coria Jr. ha equilibrado la búsqueda de obtener un título en psicología en la Universidad de Illinois en Chicago (UIC) con cuidar a sus dos hermanas menores mientras viven de los beneficios de sobrevivientes que recibieron tras la muerte de su madre.</p><p>"Es muy difícil hablar de esto emocionalmente porque perdimos a nuestra madre a principios de 2025 y luego perdemos a nuestro padre de ocho a nueve meses después", dijo Coria Jr., de 21 años, al Chicago Sun-Times desde Washington, D.C., el martes.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-230000" name="module-230000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>Coria Jr. asistió al discurso sobre el Estado de la Unión en Washington el martes por la noche como invitado del representante Raja Krishnamoorthi. Ambos se conectaron después de que el padre de Coria Jr. fuera detenido a principios de octubre cerca de su complejo de apartamentos en Mount Prospect, en el distrito congresional de Krishnamoorthi.</p><p>“Es la historia de una familia que estaba pasando por una tremenda adversidad”, dijo Krishnamoorthi. "Donald Trump dice que iba tras lo peor de lo peor cuando asumió el cargo, y creo que la familia de Jaime realmente representa lo que ha terminado siendo el objetivo de los esfuerzos de Donald Trump: familias amorosas que intentan sobrevivir... y ahora él las ha separado”.</p><p>El padre de Coria Jr. pasó cuatro días en condiciones “inhumanas” en el centro de procesamiento del Servicio de Inmigración y Control de Aduanas (ICE) en Broadview, un suburbio al oeste, antes de autodeportarse a México, donde está trabajando a tiempo completo y viviendo en la casa de su infancia.</p><p>Fue metido en una sala sin ventanas con aproximadamente 60 hombres, se le negaron duchas, se le obligó a dormir en el suelo o a mantenerse de pie y fue testigo de cómo varios detenidos fueron sacados en camillas, según Krishnamoorthi. Firmó un formulario de salida voluntaria y fue deportado al día siguiente, aunque su abogado consiguió una audiencia de emergencia que podría haber detenido su remoción.</p><p>“Él decidió, prácticamente, renunciar a sus derechos”, contó Coria Jr. “En ese momento, no le hicieron saber sus opciones legales”.</p><p>Krishnamoorthi inspeccionó la instalación de Broadview en diciembre, después de que se negaran intentos anteriores, y dijo que el edificio “no estaba diseñado de ninguna manera para albergar personas”.</p><p>“Lo que muestra es que si no hay supervisión, suceden cosas malas. Y cosas malas estaban sucediendo en Broadview... Así que esa es toda la razón de más para que personas como yo desempeñen funciones de supervisión”, compartió Krishnamoorthi. “Voy a plantarme ante ellos ocho días a la semana por lo que sucedió”.</p><p>Krishnamoorthi enfatizó que la historia de Coria Jr. destaca un patrón más amplio de detenidos que son “puestos en condiciones inhumanas, coaccionados a renunciar a sus derechos y privados del debido proceso”.</p><p>Menos de un mes después de que el padre de Coria Jr. se autodeportara, una corte ordenó la liberación de 615 detenidos en un intento de “restaurar el status quo que existía antes de que la administración de Trump cambiara recientemente su interpretación de la ley de inmigración”.</p><p>Al padre de Coria Jr. recientemente se le negó una visa de inmigración durante una cita en el Consulado de México, y el abogado de la familia está trabajando en una respuesta a esa negativa, dijo Coria Jr.</p><p>También señaló que su padre “rompe la agenda de la administración de Trump” sobre los inmigrantes. Pagó impuestos cada año durante aproximadamente dos décadas, nunca debió dinero al Servicio de Impuestos Interno (IRS), nunca votó en una elección y nunca recibió beneficios del gobierno.</p><p>El padre de Coria Jr. ha sido techador durante tres décadas y desempeñó un papel fundamental en ayudar a cuidar de su esposa durante 10 años mientras luchaba contra el colangiocarcinoma, un tipo raro de cáncer de hígado.</p><p>El padre del universitario la llevó a la sala de emergencias en múltiples ocasiones y esperó hasta que ella se estabilizara antes de volver a su trabajo intensivo en mano de obra y regresar al hospital, quedándose toda la noche para asegurarse de que estaba bien.</p><p>“El oncólogo de mi mamá incluso escribió una carta hablando sobre el carácter moral de mi papá”, agregó Coria Jr. “Él nunca se enojó conmigo ni con mis hermanas [y] siempre nos daba consejos”.</p><p>Coria Jr. insta a otros que tuvieron seres queridos detenidos en condiciones severas en Broadview a alzar la voz.</p><p>“La forma en que tratamos a las personas no es algo que debería estar en debate”, agregó Coria Jr. “Nosotros como país deberíamos esperar un mejor trato para los inmigrantes en general”.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>

entries.title: Trump's bluster isn't fooling most Americans
entries.summary: <p>State of the Union speeches haven’t mattered in a while. Even in their heyday, they were only bringing in 60 million-plus viewers, and that’s been declining substantially for decades. They rarely result in a post-speech bump for any president, and according to <a class="Link" href="https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/why-the-state-of-the-union-doesnt-have-a-big-political-impact/#:~:text=Second%2C%20State%20of%20the%20Union,isn't%20very%20much)." target="_blank" >Gallup polling data</a> since 1978, the average change in a president’s approval rating has been less than 1 percentage point in either direction.</p><p>To be sure, this is good news for Donald Trump. The president should hope and pray this State of the Union was lightly watched.</p><p>His speech was a chaotic cacophony of lies, bigotry, gaslighting and willful ignorance, painting the portrait of a man who has lost the country, and he knows it.</p><p>If Trump is confident about the state of the union, the health of the Republican Party and keeping the majority come November, his unhinged and delusional address belied that confidence. Instead, his cartoonish overcompensating for a disastrous first year only drove home the point that his administration is spiraling out of control and has no plans to change course.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-200000" name="module-200000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnist </div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Columnist</div> </div><p>Sounding very much like Joe Biden and Kamala Harris — who, I’ll remind you, lost all seven swing states in 2024 — Trump bragged about a country and economy that most Americans don’t recognize.</p><p>"Our nation is back: bigger, better, richer and stronger than ever before," he declared. "This is the golden age of America."</p><p>Few Americans feel that way, however. Polls show Trump’s job <a class="Link" href="https://www.yahoo.com/news/politics/article/poll-trumps-approval-rating-hits-new-low-as-immigration-backlash-grows-and-ice-withdraws-from-minnesota-204723473.html" target="_blank" >approval</a> is at an all-time low. Most Americans think Trump is moving the country in the <a class="Link" href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/23/trump-poll-state-of-the-union" target="_blank" >wrong direction</a>, and a plurality believes Trump is doing a <a class="Link" href="https://www.axios.com/2026/02/12/trump-polling-approval-biden-democrats" target="_blank" >worse job</a> than Biden. Most think he’s focused on issues that aren’t very important to them, and a <a class="Link" href="https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2026/02/04/a-year-into-trumps-second-term-americans-views-of-the-economy-remain-negative/" target="_blank" >majority</a> say they are very concerned about the cost of health care, food, consumer goods and housing. Less than a third of Americans <a class="Link" href="https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2026/02/04/a-year-into-trumps-second-term-americans-views-of-the-economy-remain-negative/" target="_blank" >believe</a> the economy will be better in a year.</p><p>This anxiety over the economy and health of the country could not match Trump’s bombastic gloating any less. Americans are worried and frustrated and in no mood for Trump’s delusional victory laps.</p><p>He didn’t fare much better on immigration, another one of Trump’s signature issues. In April of 2025, 48% of Americans approved of Trump’s handling of immigration. In the months following, which saw U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement surges in major cities, ugly confrontations with citizens, the unlawful detainment of several undocumented immigrants and the shocking deaths of two protesters, his approval has dipped to a low of 41%, with his disapproval skyrocketing to 55%.</p><p>There was no acknowledgment of this or attempt at a course-correction in his speech, though. Instead, he played to the cheapest of seats with gory tales of violence by illegal drug lords, murderers and rapists — criminals no one has an issue with removing.</p><p>Finally, on tariffs, Trump told voters the sky was green.</p><p>"Everything was working well," before the Supreme Court shot them down, he insisted, and said that "factories, jobs, investment and trillions and trillions of dollars will continue pouring into America" because of those tariffs.</p><p>But according to independent estimates, his tariffs <a class="Link" href="https://www.yahoo.com/news/politics/article/state-of-the-union-takeawa-050313481.html?guccounter=1" target="_blank" >have cost</a> U.S. households as much as $2,600 per year, and polls show a majority of Americans oppose them.</p><p>Now, if he doesn’t want to listen to voters, that’s certainly his prerogative, and I imagine Democrats won’t get in his way. Republican lawmakers who are up in November, though, probably wish he’d start sounding different when he talked about the economic pain most Americans were feeling.</p><p>But they’d need a different president, one who isn’t delusional and totally unwilling to admit what most people can see and feel: The state of the union is bad, and Trump is to blame.</p><p><i>S.E. Cupp is the host of “S.E. Cupp Unfiltered” on CNN.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-890000" name="module-890000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. entries.title: Bears grant LB Tremaine Edmunds permission to seek a trade
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — Amid the likelihood the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> will cut him in the next three weeks for salary cap purposes, linebacker Tremaine Edmunds has been granted permission to seek a trade, a source confirmed Wednesday.</p><p>Cutting Edmunds before the start of the league year next month would save the Bears $15 million. He would count as a $17.4 million cap hit next year if he's on the roster but take merely a $2.4 million dead cap charge if he's cut. He's entering the final year of his contract.</p><p>Whether it’s a cut or a trade — the latter would net a Day 3 pick — the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/24/bears-gm-ryan-poles-must-set-aside-attachment-as-he-eyes-potential-upgrades-to-roster" target="_blank" >Bears</a> figure to make a move before the start of the league year March 11. He's due a $1 million roster bonus two days later.</p><p>Bears general manager Ryan Poles was vague when asked about Edmunds' future Tuesday.</p><p>"There's a couple guys we've got to make decisions on," he said. "You know, if that's trade, release, there's a lot of different options that … or few options that we can go down to create some space. But like I said before, this is a unique situation where we've gotten our roster in a position where we have a lot of talented players, a lot of guys getting paid well, and that puts some constraints on the cap. So we've got to make some tough decisions."</p><p>Edmunds just finished his best season as a Bear, totaling four interceptions — the second-most of any linebacker in the NFL — and leading the team in tackles despite missing four games because of a groin injury. D’Marco Jackson was named NFC Defensive Player of the Week in his place.</p><p>Jackson is a pending free agent. Longtime starter T.J. Edwards is recovering from a broken leg and Noah Sewell, who started nine games last year, is rehabbing from a torn Achilles’ tendon.</p><p>“There's some unknowns there,” Poles said. “There's some projections just in terms of return time. And then you want to know, is that athlete gonna return to be the same player he was before? Will they go downhill?’”</p><p>Edmunds doesn't turn 28 until May and has a unique blend of height and athleticism for the position.</p><p>The Bears need to get under the salary cap by the start of the league year. They could also restructure veteran contracts, though Poles has promised to be judicious with how much extra money he pushes into future years.</p><h3>No O-line shift</h3><p>The Bears need a starting left tackle with Ozzy Trapilo expected to miss most of the season with a patellar tendon injury. Poles was clear Tuesday about what the Bears would not do to fill the position.</p><p>Right tackle Darnell Wright isn’t switching to left tackle, he said. Joe Thuney will stay at left guard, too. He played well in a spot start at left tackle against the Rams but won the NFL’s first-ever Protector of the Year Award at his natural position.</p><p>“We like him at left guard,” Poles said.</p><p>The free agent tackle class isn’t considered a strong one, but it would get markedly better if the 49ers decide to cut star Trent Williams. The two are talking about an extension to lower his cap number for 2026 and 49ers GM John Lynch said this week they are “on the right track.”</p><h3>London games</h3><p>The Jaguars will be the home team for two games in London — one at Wembley Stadium and one at Tottenham Hotspur Stadium —  and the Commanders will play a home game at Tottenham. </p><p>The NFL made the announcement Wednesday, one day after saying the Lions will be the home team for a game in Germany.</p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" entries.title: Trump’s countless lies 'normalized and cruel'
entries.summary: <p>It’s not a lie if you believe it.</p><p>President Donald Trump must recite that mantra in the mirror daily. During the longest <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/donald-trump/2026/02/24/president-donald-trump-state-of-the-union-speech-illinois-democrats-boycott" >State of the Union</a> address in history, he rambled a fusillade of falsehoods and superlatives. In the face of <a class="Link" href="https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2026/01/29/confidence-in-trump-dips-and-fewer-now-say-they-support-his-policies-and-plans/" target="_blank" ><u>low approval ratings</u></a>, he fell back on his media mastery — distractions, trumped-up narratives and delusions.</p><p>"Our country is winning again. In fact, we're winning so much that we really don't know what to do about it. People are asking me, please, please, please, Mr. President, we're winning too much. We can't take it anymore," Trump said. He sounded like a casino carny. </p><p>"We're not used to winning in our country. Until you came along, we were just always losing, but now we're winning too much. And I say no, no, no, you're going to win again. You're going to win big; you're going to win bigger than ever."</p><p>The golden age of America is here, he said. Because of his leadership, what once was a dead country a year ago is now the hottest. Spirit is restored alongside a stacked military and police force. Unfortunately, Trump’s insolence toward immigrants, and Somalis in particular, was on brand, as was his trash-talking or scolding of detractors. After a year in office, Trump said he ended eight wars, virtually stopped drugs from entering the United States and prevented "illegal aliens" from voting. He continued the lie of voter fraud and election cheating. Trump’s lying is normalized and cruel. The speech is what I expected. This is the nation in his mind’s eye.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-f80000" name="module-f80000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnist </div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Columnist</div> </div><p><a class="Link" href="https://www.politifact.com/article/2026/feb/25/Donald-trump-state-union-green/" target="_blank" ><u>Politifact</u></a>, an independent fact-checking newsroom, kept busy Tuesday night rating and debunking the president’s lies in real time. Politifact takes statements and provides clarity, context or call-outs. It’s an important piece of public service in our democracy, but in an oversaturated media landscape in which TikTok influencers are just as trusted as daily news reporters, facts get lost. If the president in all his authoritative hectoring describes low gas prices, that bluster can convince Americans that he must be right — despite what they see at the pump. Or at minimum, Trump sows confusion.</p><p>For years, the mainstream media hesitated to use the word "lie" to describe Trump’s actions. Politifact founder Bill Adair pulls the curtain back in his 2024 book "Beyond the Big Lie: The Epidemic of Political Lying, Why Republicans Do It More, and How It Could Burn Down Our Democracy." Early on, he recounts when he was asked by a caller on C-SPAN if he could say whether Democrats or Republicans lie more often. Adair knew the answer, but he lied because he wanted to show fairness.</p><p>"I, like most Washington journalists, was afraid Republicans would call me biased. My job was difficult enough because of the nature of fact-checking, a challenging job in which we declared what was true and what was false," he writes. To be fair, Democrats lie, too. Adair’s desire to appear fair did the opposite. While "Beyond the Big Lie" isn’t focused on Trump, Adair attempts to be a corrective to that C-SPAN caller.</p><p>Trump’s lies are exhausting. During his State of the Union speech, he also bragged about lifting 2.4 million people out of food assistance when he actually kicked them off. While the president didn’t name-check Chicago, he asked lawmakers to "end deadly sanctuary cities that protect the criminals and enact serious penalties for public officials who block the removal of criminal aliens, in many cases, drug lords, murderers all over our country" — a clear dig at cities that welcome migrants and clear misinformation about who they are.</p><p>Toward the end of the nearly two-hour speech, the U.S.A. chants and awarding of medals tamped down. Trump painted the country in hues reminiscent of "America the Beautiful" lyrics. The emperor wore a red tie in the House Chamber. No mention of the recent deaths of people at the hands of masked federal agents under the guise of immigration enforcement; he treated the horrors in Minnesota and Illinois as ephemeral as Snapchat, but the Trump lies are as lasting as forever plastics.</p><p>Because it’s still a lie even if you believe it.</p><p><i>Natalie Y. Moore is a senior lecturer at Northwestern University.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-db0000" name="module-db0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>
